description: From Middle English outwith, outewith, a transposed variant of Middle English withoute (“without”); equivalent to out +‎ with. Cognate to Scots ootwi.

entries.meaning: (now chiefly Scotland) Outside; beyond; outside of. [from 12th c.]
examples: All at once he’d wanted to buy a place there, but it had been too isolated for his wife – and outwith their means anyway.
